elements.text:
btnp([b], [pl]) returns whether the button "b" is
down in the current frame and wasn't down
during the previous frame.
[b]
  an integer from 0 to 15 indicating the
value of the button being pressed.

b values:
0: Keyboard Left Arrow / Left Stick Left
1: Keyboard Right Arrow / Left Stick Right
2: Keyboard Up Arrow / Left Stick Up
3: Keyboard Down Arrow / Left Stick Down
4: Keyboard Z / Controller A
5: Keyboard X / Controller X
6: Keyboard ENTER / Controller Pause
8: Keyboard A / Right Stick Left
9: Keyboard D / Right Stick Right
10: Keyboard W / Right Stick Up
11: Keyboard S / Right Stick Down
12: Keyboard F / Controller B
13: Keyboard G / Controller Y
14: Keyboard Q / Left Bumper
15: Keyboard E / Right Bumper

As you may have noticed, 7 does not have an
assigned button or key.
The code below prints the last pressed button.
[pl]'s behavior has yet to be added here. @ewanpeebles get to work on this
Parameters in brackets can be omitted.

function _init()
cbtn = "none"
end
function _update()
if btnp(0) then cbtn = "Left Arrow / Left Stick Left"
elseif btnp(1) then cbtn = "Right Arrow / Left Stick Right"
elseif btnp(2) then cbtn = "Up Arrow / Left Stick Up"
elseif btnp(3) then cbtn = "Down Arrow / Left Stick Down"
elseif btnp(4) then cbtn = "Keyboard Z / Controller A"
elseif btnp(5) then cbtn = "Keyboard X / Controller X"
elseif btnp(6) then cbtn = "Keyboard ENTER / Controller Pause"
elseif btnp(7) then cbtn = "You found it"
elseif btnp(8) then cbtn = "Keyboard A / Right Stick Left"
elseif btnp(9) then cbtn = "Keyboard D / Right Stick Right"
elseif btnp(10) then cbtn = "Keyboard W / Right Stick Up"
elseif btnp(11) then cbtn = "Keyboard S / Right Stick Down"
elseif btnp(12) then cbtn = "Keyboard F / Controller B"
elseif btnp(13) then cbtn = "Keyboard G / Controller Y"
elseif btnp(14) then cbtn = "Keyboard Q / Left Bumper"
elseif btnp(15) then cbtn = "Keyboard E / Right Bumper"
 end
end
function _draw()
cls()
print(cbtn)
end

For a function that only checks if the button
is down, see btn().
